answers.answer: Dear 1.1.:The spectrum of all of your questions certainly are comprehensive and likely should be answered in depth, beyond the scope of this service.  Briefly, yes MS can present with whole body symptoms but this would be extraordinarily rare.  Yes, MS can be present without brain lesions, also uncommon but does happen.  Yes, MS can occur just in the spinal cord and anywhere in the spinal cord, but is usually more common in the cervical cord.  Yes, MS can cause aches and pains, especially as the spasticity increases.  The exacerbations of MS can last anywhere from a few days to continual for the rest of the patients life (the latter is rare except for the malignant forms of MS).Sorry, I couldn't get into more depth.  I would visit the Multiple Sclerosis site on the internet for more indepth information.Sincerely,CCF Neuro MD

One test I had showed a high blood sugar test.  Can diabetes mimic MS symptoms (eyes twitching and other twitches, pin pricks, tingling and numbness, and other sensory sensations?)  Thanks for your answer!
Dear 1.1.:Yes, hypoglycemia can give you sensory changes and muscle twitches.  Too high of sugar with ketosis (not using your insulin) over a period of time can induce a polyneuropathy.CCF Neuro MD

I have a question for the neurologist.  Please explain the "malignant forms of MS"?  Is that the same as primary progressive?  I have MS and was not aware of such a classification as "malignant forms".  Thanks for your help.

question: A few questions about MS.  I have read it is unusual for MS to present with widespread sensory disturbance, but is it unheard of?  Also, can MS be present if lesions are not detected on MRIs?  Where on the spine are lesions detected (cervical, lumbar, thoracic, brain?) CAn they be on any of these places?  Does MS have an aches and pains component? What about a twitching component? Do lesions develop early in the disease or can they develop later? I know symptoms wax and wane.  What is the general time period for these to continue (months, days?)Thank you for your help.
